DIV1.P: A COMIC OPERA: AS IT IS ACTED AT THE THEATRE-ROYAL, SMOKE-ALLEY.

DIV2.HEAD: ACT I.
DIV2.STAGE: SCENE Discovers COLLIN, PHOEBE, two THRESH∣ERS, and two WOMEN Spinning.

SP.SPEAKER: CHORUS.
SP.L: HOW free from remorse, vexation and strife,
Are the labours and sports of the villagers life,
How free from remorse, vexation and strife
Are the labours and sports of the villagers life,
Are the labours and sports of the villagers life.

SP.SPEAKER: TRIO.
SP.L: All our time is well spent,
All our time is well spent,

SP.SPEAKER: CHORUS.
SP.L: And we reap the rich harvest of health and content,
And we reap the rich harvest of health and content.

SP.SPEAKER: DUETTO,
SP.L: And those pangs of the heart,

SP.SPEAKER: Co.
SP.P: Stay a little longer my dear Phoebe, I have no pleasure but in your company, in your innocent smiles and endearing conversation, you have scarce been with me an hour, is that too much for love, when you would sacrifice your whole life to duty.

SP.SPEAKER: Phoe.
SP.P: Oh fye Colin, can you talk so, hav'n't I listen∣ed to you all the morning? Didn't you meet me as I came out of the wood, where I had been to carry my father's breakfast, and is it not now almost noon, for see every body is going to dinner, what do you think my mother will say.

SP.SPEAKER: Co.
SP.P: One moment more I conjure. [Holding her.

SP.SPEAKER: Phoe.
SP.P: Let me go Colin, you know what a noise she always makes, I had a great deal of anger about the nosegay which you gave me, indeed she rated and ques∣tioned me all day about it, to appease her I was fain to say I had gathered it myself, but I won't tell any more stories for you Colin. Let me go.

SP.SPEAKER: Phoe.
SP.L: What a scolding I got t'other day for the flow'r,
Which kneeling you forc'd me to chuse;
Your look was so tender I had not the pow'r,
I had not the will to refuse.
Ah treacherous Colin, that rose-bud I doubt
A thorn in my bosom has been,
While artful you strove to adorn it without,
You pilfer'd, you pilfer'd, its peace from within,
You pilfer'd, you pilfer'd, its peace from within.

SP.SPEAKER: Co.
SP.P: My dear angel Phoebe.

SP.SPEAKER: Phe.
SP.P: If my mher should catch us together, it will cause a great deal of mischief, as she is determined I shall marry Farmer Wheatear.

SP.SPEAKER: Co.
SP.P: Farmer Wheatear!

SP.SPEAKER: Ph.
SP.P: Yes, her old friend and neighbour, who is a rich widower, and a more suitable match than you, as she says, as he is arrived at years of discretion.

SP.SPEAKER: Co.
SP.P: What do I hear! will Phoebe forsake me, I had no joy in life, but the hopes of passing it with her, and though I'd nothing but myself to offer, I fondly fancied Phoebe's heart would make me richer than a king. See how I'm distress'd, and if you have no love, be not wholly destitute of compassion.

SP.SPEAKER: Co.
SP.L: And you drive me to despair.

SP.SPEAKER: Ph.
SP.P: Hark! don't you hear my father at work hard by, he'll certainly discover us—Lets retire.

SP.SPEAKER: Co.
SP.P: How much I love you Phoebe.

SP.SPEAKER: Ph.
SP.P: And I believe I love you—but not much, re∣member.

SP.SPEAKER: Co.
SP.P: Charming maid—but the farmer.

SP.SPEAKER: Ph.
SP.P: Let me alone, I tell you that I will constantly refuse him, and who knows what time may bring about away, away.

SP.SPEAKER: Co.
SP.P: Then on my Phoebe's love I will rely.

LG.L: The pangs of absence I'll endure,
Content to quit my bosom's queen,
While honour chears the parting scene;
For every lonely hour shall be
For every lonely hour shall be
Employed my fair to think on thee.
When morn invites to early toil,
Thy love shall make my labours smile,
When evening calls to downy rest,
That hope shall sooth my pensive breast,

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE.
DIV3.P: Enter BOOZE, With a Hatchet, a Wicker, Bottle and a Pitcher.

SP.SPEAKER: Booze.
SP.P: Ouf, I'm all of a muck, let's take a little breath (drinks) so my dear immortal friend (hugging the bottle) a man might have a little social comfort with thee now, but for the thoughts of one's creditors, and the fear of interruptions, this it is to be plagued with ci∣vility, they-are always paying their respects to my man∣sion, and though I never return the visit they are resol∣ved to continue their kind enquiries; after all poor folks are much to be pitied, I do nothing but toil, toil, toil, and have never yet been the better for it.

LG.L: From morn to night with axe in hand,
Here in the wood I take my stand,
Without content, with sweat of brow,
My life is spent in hough, hough, hough!
But what with the bottle and the pitcher,
The devil a bit do I grow the richer;
Is the plague of my life,
Is the plague of my life,
Is the plague of my life,
Is the plague of my life
Is the plague of my life,
Is the plague of my life,
Is the plague of my life,
To be tied up like thee,
To be tied up like thee,

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.P: What shall I do, whither shall I run, the con∣tinued extravagance of my wife, has brought me to the brink of ruin, my house is beset, and I am myself ex∣posed to every disgrace, my only hope is, that the time allotted for my sojourn upon earth, is almost expired; life has never given me one real joy, and I shall yield it up again with remarkable satisfaction.

SP.SPEAKER: Booze.
SP.P: Hey! who have we here?

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.P: Save me friend! I am pursued to my destructi∣on, and cannot possibly run further.

SP.SPEAKER: Booze.
SP.P: That I believe, why who the devil advised you to put on boots, in order to ride post on oot.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.P: My horse was knocked up, and I was obliged to leave him in the wood—But I hav'n't a moment to spare, for the officers are close at my heels.

SP.SPEAKER: Booze.
SP.P: Are they so—why, who are these two ill∣looking fellows going down that hill.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.P: No less than the worthy gentry I have fled from, but as they probably return this way, only contrive some method to conceal me, and your fortune is made for ever.

SP.SPEAKER: Booze.
SP.P: May be your a highway-man.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.P: No, upon my honour.

SP.SPEAKER: Booze.
SP.P: A truce with your honour, I'll believe you full as well without it. Then perhaps you're some rich bankrupt, who has made over all his effects to himself, and would now make away with both.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.P: No, on the contrary, I am a poor devil, not worth a doit, flying from his wife and creditors.

SP.SPEAKER: Booze.
SP.P: You're right there, for I know to my cost they're the worst company a man can get into, but you talk of securing my fortune, without having a single sixpence.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.P: That don't signify.

SP.SPEAKER: Booze.
SP.P: Why to be sure, you'll not be the first man who has provided for others, without having sense e∣nough to take care of himself.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.P: I'll do better for you than giving money.

SP.SPEAKER: Booze.
SP.P: Aye! I know nothing better than that now a days.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.P: I'll grant you the accomplishment of the three first wishes ou shall form.

SP.SPEAKER: Booze.
SP.P: What! are you a wizzard?

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.P: No, I am a devil. But don't be alarmed, I'm a very good kind of one, and will do you no harm. My name is Belphegor, commanded by Pluto to as∣sume the appearance of a mortal, and reside ten years upon earth.

SP.SPEAKER: Booze.
SP.P: He might have spared himself the trouble, as we have devils enough in that shape already, but for what purpose was you sent hither?

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.P: To prove whether the continual complaints of married men against their wives, were well founded.

SP.SPEAKER: Booze.
SP.P: There is no occasion to stay ten years to be convinced of that, I fancy friend, your account will not be favourable.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.P: My disappointment shall not prejudice me a∣gainst the female world, as I am convinced there are many, who in ever respect do honour to human nature, alleviating by their tenderness, the woes of life, and by their smiles improving all their joys.

SP.SPEAKER: Booze.
SP.P: But how can I depend on you, who by your own account, don't come from the right place to be much credited; besides is it likely you can grant me three wishes, when you are not able to afford one for yourself.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.P: Nevertheless, Pluto has given me the power of rewarding you, in the manner I have promised.

SP.SPEAKER: Booze.
SP.P: And your devilship, will really supply me with whatsoever three things I chuse to desire.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.P: Be confident, and you shan't be disappointed.

SP.SPEAKER: Booze.
SP.P: Begin then by climbing over that gate into my yard.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.P: What shall I do there?

SP.SPEAKER: Booze.
SP.P: Why we are going to bake just now, and we can cram you into the oven at the same time.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.P: Zounds! that will be too hot.

SP.SPEAKER: Booze.
SP.P: I did not know you devils were afraid of bur∣ning.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.P: In taking the figure of man, I have likewise all the feelings of one.

SP.SPEAKER: Booze.
SP.P: Why then you may throw yourself down the well, you will find that cold enough I believe.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.P: You fly from one extreme to another.

SP.SPEAKER: Booze.
SP.P: Is it my fault you can neither bear heat nor cold.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.P: No matter, I will hide myself in some part of your dwelling, be careful, if my pursuers should return, not to reveal me, and perhaps you may see me again when you stand in need of my advice, but remember, it will be your own fault if you are not a happy man.

LG.L: From this moment you will be,
Wish, wish, and your wishes shall be granted.
In the space of an hour.
Then make the best use of the boon I bestow,
Nor the favours of fortune by folly o'erthrow.

SP.SPEAKER: Booze.
SP.P: So now I shall have two devils in my house at once, well, I defy this to be a greater torment to me than the other, but after all, have I done well, to put confidence in a person of his complexion? Suppose he should twist my neck off by way of recompense, impossible! He behaves exceedingly like a gentleman, and is, I dare say, a devil of honour. But now for my three wishes, (considers)—Well thought on—No, something better than that, this reasoning heats me sadly, a little mois∣ture will cool the head, and clear the understanding.

SP.SPEAKER: Din.
SP.P: Ha! monster, have I caught you.

SP.SPEAKER: Booze.
SP.P: Be sure you don't miscall me wife. Now Dame, I fancy you ll be pleased.

SP.SPEAKER: Din.
SP.P: Pleas'd indeed! is this the way to do your work?

SP.SPEAKER: Booze.
SP.P: I have done more work to-day than you ima∣gine.

SP.SPEAKER: Din.
SP.P: What work have you done? Drank all the li∣quor you can lay your hands on. [Going up to him.

SP.SPEAKER: Booze.
SP.P: Stop, don't lay hands upon me, don't be in a passion.

SP.SPEAKER: Din.
SP.P: Not be in a passion, drunkard, not in a passion.

SP.SPEAKER: Booze.
SP.P: Well, be in a passion if you like it.

SP.SPEAKER: Din.
SP.P: I'm sure, I have reason enough.

LG.L: Each day all the work of the house I must do,
I sew and I knit and I spin,
I scrub and rub, and I bake and I brew,
The labours all left for Dame Din,
The labour's all left, the labour's all left,
The labour's all left for Dame Din.
And while every comfort we cannot afford
On my children's account, I refuse
My husband as great and as drunk as a lord,
Thinks the pleasure is all for Sir Booze,
But you rascal you villain, you hang dog, you fot
No longer this plan I'll pursue,
For since family duties are daily forgot,
Dame Din will have her pleasures too.

SP.SPEAKER: Booze.
SP.P: Why wie I say,

SP.SPEAKER: Din.
SP.P: Your wife! you have no regard for either her or your children, ar'n't you over head and ears in debt to the whole village?

SP.SPEAKER: Booze.
SP.P: In debt! what does that signify?

SP.SPEAKER: Din.
SP.P: Don't they threaten us every day with sending us to prison, and shan't we be oblig'd to come upon the parish for support.

SP.SPEAKER: Booze.
SP.P: Its more likely the parish will come upon us.

SP.SPEAKER: Din.
SP.P: Here's been several of your creditors this morn∣ing, who swear they won't wait another day, I dare say we shall have them again.

SP.SPEAKER: Booze.
SP.P: I shall be glad to see 'em.

SP.SPEAKER: Din.
SP.P: But you won't be glad to hear them.

SP.SPEAKER: Booze.
SP.P: Not unless their voices are a little softer than yours.

SP.SPEAKER: Din.
SP.P: I have no patience! will you think of providing for your daughter Phoebe, Farmer Wheatear demands her in marriage, his fortune will assist us.

SP.SPEAKER: Booze.
SP.P: His fortune! Pish.

SP.SPEAKER: Din.
SP.P: He's rich.

SP.SPEAKER: Booze.
SP.P: Rich! Farmer Wheatear rich!

SP.SPEAKER: Din.
SP.P: Who then will you give her to?

SP.SPEAKER: Booze.
SP.P: To the squire.

SP.SPEAKER: Din.
SP.P: Do you dream?

SP.SPEAKER: Booze.
SP.P: To a lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Din.
SP.P: Are you drunk?

SP.SPEAKER: Booze.
SP.P: To the King.

SP.SPEAKER: Din.
SP.P: Are you mad?

SP.SPEAKER: Booze.
SP.P: That you'll find out by and by.

SP.SPEAKER: Din.
SP.P: What nonsense!

SP.SPEAKER: Booze.
SP.P: In a word, I am the happiest of men, and if you're wise, you shall be the happiest of women, I have more power than the high sheriff, and more wealth than a nabob.

SP.SPEAKER: Din.
SP.P: He's certainly out of his mind.

SP.SPEAKER: Booze.
SP.P: Did you see a person in boots slip thro' the key hole just now, as you came out.

SP.SPEAKER: Din.
SP.P: Certainly mad! no, how should I?

SP.SPEAKER: Booze.
SP.P: Well, listen. Standing exactly where we now are, wearied to death with my morning's work, grum∣bling at our hard fate, and cursing from my soul your diabolical temper.

SP.SPEAKER: Din
SP.P: How traitor, have you any thing to reproach me with?

SP.SPEAKER: Booze.
SP.P: We'll leave that subject at present, but as I was saying all of a sudden, a demon.

SP.SPEAKER: Din.
SP.P: Heaven forbid.

SP.SPEAKER: Booze.
SP.P: At the noise of my complaint, came to my assistance.

SP.SPEAKER: Din.
SP.P: And have you sold yourself Booze?

SP.SPEAKER: Booze.
SP.P: No, no, he's only an unhappy devil like my∣self, who has been plagued these ten years with a cla∣morous wife, and a tumultuous set of creditors, I have lent him my assistance to get rid of the latter, and for the rest, he must turn philosopher like me, and put up with it. In recompence for this favour he assured me—

SP.SPEAKER: Din.
SP.P: What has he assured you?

SP.SPEAKER: Booze.
SP.P: That I might at my option form three wish∣es—

SP.SPEAKER: Din.
SP.P: I could form a thousand, for instance, To see you a little more reasonable, one! To see you work more, two! To see you drink less, three!

SP.SPEAKER: Booze.
SP.P: And that all the three should be accomplished.

SP.SPEAKER: Din.
SP.P: Accomplished! seriously.

SP.SPEAKER: Booze.
SP.P: That's the fact.

SP.SPEAKER: Din
SP.P: Three wishes!

SP.SPEAKER: Booze.
SP.P: Certainly.

SP.SPEAKER: Din.
SP.P: And for three different things, isn't it so.

SP.SPEAKER: Booze.
SP.P: Without doubt.

SP.SPEAKER: Din.
SP.P: Ch charming! Three Wishes, delightful!

SP.SPEAKER: Booze.
SP.P: I am a drunkard, am I?

SP.SPEAKER: Din.
SP.P: No, no.

SP.SPEAKER: Booze.
SP.P: A hang dog.

SP.SPEAKER: Din.
SP.P: Be quiet. (stopping his mouth)

SP.SPEAKER: Booze.
SP.P: A man that don't love his wife.

SP.SPEAKER: Din.
SP.P: O yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Booze.
SP.P: Nor his children.

SP.SPEAKER: Din.
SP.P: Will you never have done? who could tell.

SP.SPEAKER: Booze.
SP.P: Well, well, shake hands Dame, good fortune makes friends of every body.

SP.SPEAKER: Din.
SP.P: You hav'n't begun to wish yet I hope.

SP.SPEAKER: Booze.
SP.P: No, that's the difficulty.

SP.SPEAKER: Din.
SP.P: Be sure to take care how to proceed. Three Wishes! there are but three remember, it is not as if there were a hundred.

SP.SPEAKER: Booze.
SP.P: That's true enough.

SP.SPEAKER: Din.
SP.P: If your dear wife now should think of something.

SP.SPEAKER: Booze.
SP.P: Don't be in a hurry, two heads are better than one you know, I'll go and consult with squire Solemn the Justice.

SP.SPEAKER: Din.
SP.P: Suppose you invite him to our house, my love, then we may all consider the matter over at the same time.

SP.SPEAKER: Booze.
SP.P: I will so, I dare say he'll come, he's not proud in the least, I once sat within two of him at the parish meeting. He doesn't indeed say much but then he's an excellent head. [Exit.

LG.L: In grave debate they only grate,
The learn'd and wise when they advise,
Look big, but hold their tongue.
Thus female wit is seldom fit,
Therefore in life the prudent wife,

SP.SPEAKER: Din.
SP.P: What a change! it seems like a dream—farewell to spinning and brown bread.—No more Dame Din, but Madam Din, or my Ladyship Din, I shall sit in the great pew in the church, my hair shall be drest, and powder'd, and stand bolt up on an end, with a band round it like a wheatsheaf—I'll look under my eyes, so, at my neighbours—I'll dine at midnight, and get up in the afternoon—Lord what a life will that be.

SP.SPEAKER: Din.
SP.L: With a train at my tail,
With a train at my tail,

SP.SPEAKER: Din.
SP.L: In a coach I'll be drawn,
In a coach I'll be drawn,
There I'll loll and I'll Yawn,

SP.SPEAKER: Din.
SP.L: We'll live like the ladies, the ladies in tow
Our friends and relations and relations un∣known.

SP.SPEAKER: Wheat.
SP.P: Don't let me discompose you Dame, you seem very well satisfied with yourself to day—may one ask the reason.

SP.SPEAKER: Din.
SP.P: Its not without reason I assure you—but per∣haps I won't open my mouth for a twelve month.

SP.SPEAKER: Wheat.
SP.P: Not open your mouth for a twelve month, that would be a wonder indeed.

SP.SPEAKER: Din.
SP.P: You think so Farmer, do you.

SP.SPEAKER: Wheat.
SP.P: Aye that I do.

SP.SPEAKER: Din.
SP.P: The whole village will burst with envy.

SP.SPEAKER: Wheat.
SP.P: Dame Din.

SP.SPEAKER: Din.
SP.P: Yes the whole village.

SP.SPEAKER: Wheat.
SP.P: It seems to have taken away your hearing.

SP.SPEAKER: Din.
SP.P: Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Wheat.
SP.P: I say my wedding with Phoebe must shortly take place.

SP.SPEAKER: Din.
SP.P: Your wedding with Phoebe! Farmer Wheat∣ear's wedding with Phoebe! ha, ha, ha!

SP.SPEAKER: Wheat.
SP.P: Ha, ha, ha! I can contain no longer—did not you give me▪your promise?

SP.SPEAKER: Din.
SP.P: I have some faint remembrance of it.

SP.SPEAKER: Wheat.
SP.P: But not to displease you Dame, you take upon yourself a great deal, yesterday you thought me a good match for your daughter.

SP.SPEAKER: Din.
SP.P: True, yesterday Farmer Wheatear's offer was ac∣ceptable, but this is another day and all days are not a∣like.

SP.SPEAKER: Wheat.
SP.P: How, are not you the same you was yesterday; Dame Din▪ wife of Booze, a poor labouring man; and am not I Farmer Wheatear, the richest farmer in the parish.

SP.SPEAKER: Din
SP.P: Yes you are, and always will be the rich Farm∣er Wheatear, but I shall not be Dame Din much longer, nor will Phoebe be the daughter of Booze the poor la∣bouring man. [Exit curtsying.

SP.SPEAKER: Wheat
SP.P: She raves, she's out of her mind, but I'll go seek her husband if he should luckily happen to be sober, I may chance to get it explained. Did not my regard to Phoebe force me to persist, I would leave this extra∣ordinary couple entirely to themselves.

DIV3.HEAD: SONG Wheatear.

LG.L: But in vain we think to find

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Dame Din, Constable and Creditors.

SP.SPEAKER: Miller.
SP.L: For five sacks of Barley, two bushels of Rye,
In all seven pounds, cast up, try.

SP.SPEAKER: Cho. Cred.
SP.P: I'll be paid, I'll be paid, so will I.

SP.SPEAKER: Miller.
SP.P: I'll be paid.

SP.SPEAKER: Cho.
SP.P: I'll be paid, so will I, so will I, &c.

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.P: Hey neighbours, what the devil's the matter.

SP.SPEAKER: Cho.
SP.P: My bill, my bill, my bill, my bill, my bill, my bill, my bill.

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.P: Zounds, zounds! what a clatter, zounds what a clatter!
'Tis the husband you should seek.

SP.SPEAKER: Miller.
SP.P: He's so drunk he cannot speak.

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.P: Or sober or drunk, or sober or drunk, to secure him
I'll try to assist him, I'll try,

SP.SPEAKER: Miller.
SP.P: I'll be paid.

SP.SPEAKER: Cho.
SP.P: So will I, &c. &c.

SP.SPEAKER: Chand.
SP.P: Woman. I'll be paid.

SP.SPEAKER: Cho.
SP.P: So will I, &c. &c.

SP.SPEAKER: Din.
SP.P: What care I.

SP.SPEAKER: Ale-house keeper.
SP.P: I'll be paid

SP.SPEAKER: Cho.
SP.P: So will I, &c. &c.

SP.SPEAKER: Din.
SP.P: What care I.

SP.SPEAKER: Ale-house keeper.
SP.P: I'll be paid.

SP.SPEAKER: Cho.
SP.P: So will I, so will I, &c. &c. &c.

DIV2.HEAD: ACT II.
DIV2.STAGE: SCENE The Country, COLIN, PHOEBE, Dame DIN, and Farmer WHEATEAR in their best Cloaths.

SP.SPEAKER: PHOEBE.
SP.P: IS it true mother, that we are going to be so vastly rich—my father told me.

SP.SPEAKER: Din.
SP.P:
Hold your tongue, chit, these are not mat∣ters
for you to pry into, however you must think no more of Farmer Wheatear.

SP.SPEAKER: Wheat.
SP.P: But neighbour

SP.SPEAKER: Din.
SP.P: But neighbour—Will you obey Phoebe?

SP.SPEAKER: Ph.
SP.P: Certainly mother.

SP.SPEAKER: Din.
SP.P: There's a good child, but you should call me mama, now come and kiss me, Phoebe since you're so tractable, but hold up your head and look jauntly, I have got a husband for you that you'll like a thousand times better.

SP.SPEAKER: Ph.
SP.P: My dear mama, how much I am obliged to you, Colin is indeed the most amiable.

SP.SPEAKER: Diu.
SP.P: How Colin—What Colin?

SP.SPEAKER: Wheat.
SP.P: Why don't you kiss her, when she's so tractable.

SP.SPEAKER: Din.
SP.P: So, so, now I discover the history of the nose∣gay, and the reason why you are so long in coming from the wood, but no matter, you must give up this most amiable Colin immediately.

SP.SPEAKER: Ph.
SP.P: Ah! be not so unkind!

LG.L: As yet in the morn of my youth,
But oh while you cherish my truth,
My passion's not founded on time,
Young Colin first taught it to glow,
And the breast which hath kindled for him,
No warmth for another can know.
To Colin as constant I'll prove,
For the heart that to duty is true,
Will always be faithful to love.

SP.SPEAKER: Din.
SP.P: And you are determin'd to think of Colin, per∣verse minx, are you.

SP.SPEAKER: Ph.
SP.P: It is impossible to help thinking of him, I can never forget Colin while I live.

SP.SPEAKER: Din.
SP.P: You impudent hussey, that [Going to strike her,

SP.SPEAKER: Wheat.
SP.P: Soft, soft, Dame (receives the blow) the devil's in the woman.

SP.SPEAKER: Din.
SP.P: Now I fancy yon'll obey me madam Pert, but I forgot the great affair all this time, while I am loite∣ring here, my husband may commit some folly, its ne∣cessary I should always be at his elbow.

LG.L: As a word and a blow,
They conquer who brandish the best stick,
What mortal will find out her merit,
There's nought like a woman of spirit. [Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Ph.
SP.P: I'm quite concerned Farmer Wheatear.

SP.SPEAKER: Wheat.
SP.P: For what my lovely girl.

SP.SPEAKER: Ph.
SP.P: For the box which you received on my account.

SP.SPEAKER: Wheat.
SP.P: Never mind it Phoebe, my cheek is more a∣ble to bear it than this soft one. [Patting her cheek.

SP.SPEAKER: Ph.
SP.P: My mother has a heavy hand.

SP.SPEAKER: Wheat.
SP.P: Rather so.

SP.SPEAKER: Ph.
SP.P: I hope it did not hurt you much.

SP.SPEAKER: Wheat.
SP.P: Now all the pain is fled▪ and if you would but think of me for a husband.

SP.SPEAKER: Ph.
SP.P: Think of you for a husband, Mr Wheatear, that's impossible.

SP.SPEAKER: Wheat.
SP.P: Why my little dear, with me you shall enjoy all the pleasures of life.

SP.SPEAKER: Ph.
SP.P:
Alas Farmer, I am very young, and unexperi∣enced,
but I thought all the pleasures of life cannot be en∣joyed till the heart is at ease—Colin's company, his love and his esteem are all that I desire.

SP.SPEAKER: Wheat.
SP.P: Poor girl, I pity her, her mother has refused me, the daughter is in love with another, I am no longer young, can I blame her, why then should I persist in making her wretched?—Phoebe

SP.SPEAKER: Ph.
SP.P: What say you Farmer.

SP.SPEAKER: Wheat.
SP.P: So you are determined to mary no other but Colin.

SP.SPEAKER: Ph.
SP.P: That I never will.

SP.SPEAKER: Wheat.
SP.P: Then I am determined [Affcting anger.

SP.SPEAKER: Ph.
SP.P: To do what!—I hope you won't distress me more.

SP.SPEAKER: Wheat.
SP.P: To go this moment to your father and en∣deavour to get his consent for you—to marry Colin.

SP.SPEAKER: Ph.
SP.P: Dear Farmer how shall I thank you.

SP.SPEAKER: Ah Colin.
SP.P: come hither Colin.

SP.SPEAKER: Co.
SP.P: You seem too well engaged already.

SP.SPEAKER: Ph.
SP.P: I hope to be better engaged by and by.

SP.SPEAKER: Co.
SP.P: Why by and by, Phoebe, ar'n't you sufficiently entertained at present.

SP.SPEAKER: Wheat.
SP.P: He's jealous, but I'll not torment him, poor lad don't be uneasy, that embrace was all for love of you.

SP.SPEAKER: Co.
SP.P: Its a strange way of showing it, I never received such a proof before.

SP.SPEAKER: Ph.
SP.P: Fye Colin, but you must embrace him yourself, and thank him too, he's going to speak to my father for us.

SP.SPEAKER: Co.
SP.P: Can I believe it.

SP.SPEAKER: Wheat.
SP.P: You may, and though there won't be so much between you, there'll be more love, and that's the best stock to set up with.

LG.L: And a wedding 'twill be without pelf,
And I'll throw the stocking myself, myself,
Fall▪ lall, lall, lall, lall de rall, lall, lall,

SP.SPEAKER: Chorus.
SP.L: Fall, lall, lall, de rall, lall, lall. [Exit.

DIV2.STAGE: SCENE, A Table ready for Pudding to come up at the Wish.

SP.SPEAKER: BOOZE.
SP.P: I have seen nothing of my friend Belphegor, where the devil can e have hid himself all this time; Perhaps he has left us for a warmer climate, but then he promi∣sed to appear in case I wanted his advice—His Worship the Justice however, will make that needless; what a sine thing it is to be rich, or to have it in one's power to be so, since my adventure has been known in the vil∣lage, the quarrel has been who should oblige me most, my creditors have lost their memories, and forgot that I ever owed them a farthing—Every body is my best friend, walk in Mr Booze, come and take pot-luck with us neighbour, continually offering me all their fortune, in hopes of partaking mine, bless me, what a number of favours a person receives when he has no occasion for any.

LG.L: I hope your hearty, why so dull,
Can I assist, my purse is full,
Tho' stain'd in guilt, and sunk in vice,
But ope the door and in a trice,

SP.SPEAKER: Sol.
SP.P: Your servant friend, your servant, I am glad to see you, I am glad to hear—But I say nothing.

SP.SPEAKER: Booze.
SP.P: Thank your Worship—I expected you wou'd come, this is a very weighty affair I have upon my hands.

SP.SPEAKER: Sol.
SP.P: I know—I know—But I say nothing.

SP.SPEAKER: Booze.
SP.P: Thank your Worship, I shall have need of all your advice.

SP.SPEAKER: Sol.
SP.P: You shall be assisted, be not disturbed.

SP.SPEAKER: Booze.
SP.P: Yes, but I am very much disturbed, I don't wonder that the richest people are not the most happy, the bare expectation of it, sets me beside myself.

SP.SPEAKER: Sol.
SP.P: Don't be disturbed I say, to give advice is my fort, and all the world think themselves advantaged by it, for this reason, because my advice is excellent—But I say nothing.

SP.SPEAKER: Booze.
SP.P: So much the better.

SP.SPEAKER: Sol.
SP.P: No Lawyer, Barrister, Special Pleader or Whip∣per Snapper Attorney, dare before me—But I say nothing.

SP.SPEAKER: Booze.
SP.P: So much the better.

SP.SPEAKER: Sol.
SP.P: I am no having Justice, no mercenary, I take no brief, but then my advice is brief—I say nothing.

SP.SPEAKER: Booze.
SP.P: So much the better, so much the better,—Will your Worship take a chair. (Enter Wheatear) Good-day neighbours, come, and welcome his Wor∣ship.

SP.SPEAKER: Wheat.
SP.P: With all my heart, and I'm heartily glad to meet you.

SP.SPEAKER: Booze.
SP.P: Well Farmer, do you still love Phoebe.

SP.SPEAKER: Wheat.
SP.P:
Yes, but I have discovered somebody else
who loves her too—in a word neighbour, young Colin is the person suited to your daughter, their years, their inclinations agree, from the first of life, he has cultiva∣ted her good opinion, and now it has ripen'd into love. He ought to reap the harvest of his labour.

SP.SPEAKER: Booze.
SP.P: What wou'd your worship advise.

SP.SPEAKER: Sol.
SP.P: I say nothing.

SP.SPEAKER: Wheat.
SP.P: Indeed neighbour you must consent to their happiness.

SP.SPEAKER: Booze.
SP.P: At present I'm engaged with his Worship, on business of consequence, nothing of that sort can be settled to-day, can it Mr Justice.

SP.SPEAKER: Sol.
SP.P: Nothing.

SP.SPEAKER: Booze.
SP.P: And pray Farmer give us your company.

SP.SPEAKER: Wheat.
SP.P: Why neighbour, they say you are going to be a great man—How is this?

SP.SPEAKER: Booze.
SP.P: The very thing I wanted to communicate to you, it depends upon myself—The Justice and I, are now preparing to consult about it—You will not be one too many.

SP.SPEAKER: Wheat.
SP.P: Then it must be a treasure.

SP.SPEAKER: Booze.
SP.P: Must it think you, must I wish for a treasure—That would be no bad thing.

SP.SPEAKER: Wheat.
SP.P: There is no occasion to wish for what you have already.

SP.SPEAKER: Booze.
SP.P: I have not got it yet.

SP.SPEAKER: Wheat.
SP.P: Your wife assured me you had.

SP.SPEAKER: Booze.
SP.P: My wife's a fool.

SP.SPEAKER: Wheat.
SP.P: I thought as much.

SP.SPEAKER: Din.
SP.P: My stars are you here old—

SP.SPEAKER: Booze.
SP.P: And why not, the Farmer is a man of under∣standing—He will assist us—Besides his Worship has been beating his brains this hour without producing any thing, and you know—

SP.SPEAKER: Sol
SP.P: Moderation my friend—Moderation, three wishes you say—But I say nothing.

SP.SPEAKER: Wheat.
SP.P: What do you mean by three Wishes, is that the treasure?

SP.SPEAKER: Din.
SP.P: Certainly.

SP.SPEAKER: Booze.
SP.P: I'll explain it all to you. [To Wheatear.

SP.SPEAKER: Din.
SP.P: I rejoice to see your honour in our little cottage—but what will it be by and by.

SP.SPEAKER: Sol.
SP.P: I know—But I say nothing.

SP.SPEAKER: Din.
SP.P: I hope your honour won't think of listening to my husband—who between you and me, is no wiser than he should be—I am but a woman, and his wife, but mark me, I have more sense in my little singer.

SP.SPEAKER: Sol.
SP.P: What spirit! but affairs of this kind require very wise heads indeed—But I say nothing.

SP.SPEAKER: Wheat.
SP.P: The devil it does Mr Booze.

SP.SPEAKER: Booze.
SP.P: Well Mr Justice.

SP.SPEAKER: Sol.
SP.P: Don't interrupt me.

SP.SPEAKER: Wheat.
SP.P: I long to see the end of this business.

SP.SPEAKER: Booze.
SP.P: Suppose we sit down at the table—Your Wor∣ship will perhaps find it easier for studying.—Wife get us some Ale.

SP.SPEAKER: Wheat.
SP.P: A Lucky thought.—Good bright Ale, bright∣ens the wit.

SP.SPEAKER: Sol.
SP.P: Sometimes it does and sometimes it does not, on the contrary there are instances—and they depend upon circumstances in hopes—But I say nothing.

SP.SPEAKER: Booze.
SP.P: That's right, now sit down.
SP.STAGE: [To his wife who is coming with the Ale.

SP.SPEAKER: Wheat.
SP.P: Room, room for my Lady.

SP.SPEAKER: Booze.
SP.P: The nearer I approach the grand moment the more I am disquieted.

SP.SPEAKER: Sol.
SP.P: Like enough—like enough.

SP.SPEAKER: Wheat.
SP.P: Let's drink and keep up our spirits.

SP.SPEAKER: Sol.
SP.P: Moderation, gentlemen, moderation.

DIV2.STAGE: [Takes the tankard from him and takes a long draught.

SP.SPEAKER: Wheat.
SP.P: I think you have rather too much Mr Justice.

SP.SPEAKER: Sol.
SP.P: Wish Booze.

SP.SPEAKER: Din.
SP.P: Now we are come to it.

SP.SPEAKER: Sol.
SP.P: In the first place your Cellar to be always well stored.

SP.SPEAKER: Din.
SP.P: That's nothing at all.—Your Wife to be always handsome.

SP.SPEAKER: Booze.
SP.P: Psha I want fortune—and a handsome wife is of more use to the gallant than the husband—don't you think so Mr Justice.

SP.SPEAKER: Sol.
SP.P: I say nothing.

SP.SPEAKER: Booze.
SP.P: But if your Worship still continues saying no∣thing we shall never come to the end of our business.

SP.SPEAKER: Din.
SP.P: We are not nearer now than we were at the be∣ginning.

SP.SPEAKER: Wheat.
SP.P: Let's employ the tankard perhaps we shall find it at the bottom.

SP.SPEAKER: Booze.
SP.P: Drink as much as you please if that will do, but we ought to have something to eat at the same time see what there is in the pantry.—I am told your loves a hunting Pudding, we had an excellent one last Sunday—I wish with all my heart we had such another now. [Pudding appears upon table.

SP.SPEAKER: Din.
SP.P: A Pudding! [starting.

SP.SPEAKER: Wheat.
SP.P: Good soul.

SP.SPEAKER: Sol.
SP.P: Moderation I tell you.—I never tasted a nicer dish in all my life.

SP.SPEAKER: Wheat.
SP.P: And I fancy our landlord thinks it a dear one.

SP.SPEAKER: Booze.
SP.P: I have been to blame, I own it, but we have two wishes remaining.

SP.SPEAKER: Din.
SP.P: Two devils.

SP.SPEAKER: Booze.
SP.P: True, and I can't tell which torments me most.

SP.SPEAKER: Sol.
SP.P: If you scold all day it won't mend the matter. [His mouth full.

SP.SPEAKER: Din.
SP.P: Yes dunderhead, when you might have had a kingdom full of gold, you wish'd for a pudding—go—shall indeed—I won't say what.

SP.SPEAKER: Sol.
SP.P: That's right don't say what.

SP.SPEAKER: Din.
SP.P: If I had been to have wish'd—You shou'd have seen—You shou'd have seen.

SP.SPEAKER: Booze.
SP.P: Hold your tongue, railing, scolding, vixen, hold your tongue—I wish you'd lost the use of it.

SP.SPEAKER: Wheat.
SP.P: Two wishes disposed of ha, ha, ha!

SP.SPEAKER: Sol.
SP.P: This it is not to have moderation, and as this is the case, I have no further business here, nevertheless Mr Booze for the present, I would advise you.

SP.SPEAKER: Booze
SP.P: To hang myself.

SP.SPEAKER: Sol.
SP.P: No, that's an affair of Justice—And sentence is never pronounced but in Court.

SP.SPEAKER: Booze
SP.P: Two wishes thrown away.

SP.SPEAKER: Wheat.
SP.P: But your wife neighbour▪ won't stun you with her melody any longer, that's something gain'd however.

LG.L: Cheer up my friends your cares defy,
What husband would not gladly buy
The winter checks the rising crop,
The spring we know is warmer,
For brighter hours we live and hope,
What matters now since madam's dumb,
If hence she wear the breeches,
From wife that's mute no ill can come,
Then bear your loss of riches.
No sorrow let your looks betray,
In mirth the surest truth is,
Swallow your griefs and nothing say,

DIV2.STAGE: (Thunder, Clock strikes, Belphegor comes from the case.)

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.P: Be not terrified my friends, my honest landlord knew I was his guest though concealed—I promised to appear when most he wanted my advice, and notwith∣standing his learned friend's assistance, I fear he has much occasion for it now.

SP.SPEAKER: Sol.
SP.P: What blustering gentleman is this, I am afraid he'll bring the house about our ears.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.P: What's that you say sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Sol.
SP.P: I say nothing.

SP.SPEAKER: Booze.
SP.P: This is his infernal Worship—by whose kind∣ness, added to your wise counsel, I have gained many advantages—Will you be introduced to him.

SP.SPEAKER: Sol.
SP.P: By no means, a magistrate should not be seen in such company.

SP.SPEAKER: Bel.
SP.P: I am truly concerned that my gratitude for the kindness you showed me, should have turned out so lit∣tle to your advantage—I am now summoned away, and all my wordly cares are over, anxious however for your welfare, the few moments allowed me shall be spent in endeavouring to promote it, seek no more to aggrandize yorself, nor wish for fancied pleasures, real peace; let your third wish be given to recover your domestic felici∣ty, without which, know from experience, there can be no happiness in life: Restore your wife to her speech, live temperate, be frugal and industrious, and you will probably enjoy more ease and comfort, than in the gra∣tification of the most unbounded desires.

LG.L: Then learn to prize your humble lot,
Improve the little you have got,
And when content appears in view,
You'll own the devil told you true. [Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Wheat.
SP.P: I'm glad he's gone, notwithstanding the kind lecture he gave us—I've been in a devilish fright ever since he appeared.

SP.SPEAKER: Co.
SP.P: Have they at last consented.

SP.SPEAKER: Wheat.
SP.P: Here comes madam Din, she'll tell you if she's able.

DIV2.STAGE: Enter Din. She makes signs of penitence.

SP.SPEAKER: Booze.
SP.P: All these signs will do no good.

SP.SPEAKER: Ph.
SP.P: My dear papa, have pity.

SP.SPEAKER: Booze.
SP.P: Only one wish more, come let's be a King at once, wife should you like to become a Queen.

SP.SPEAKER: Wheat.
SP.P: What a Queen, and not talk no, no (Din shakes her head) I thought so, come, come, you must forgive her, and do as your friend Lucifer advised you, for after all, I believe that will be the best way.

SP.SPEAKER: Booze
SP.P: Well I wish—I wish—That my wife may re∣cover the use of her tongue [Fetches a deep sigh.

SP.SPEAKER: Din.
SP.P: Ah my dear friend—My good husband—My kind man, embrace me again—And you Farmer—And you Colin—And you Phaebe—And all of you, I con∣sent to every thing, I oppose nothing—You have all as∣sisted me—Give me your hand Booze, and your's my children love each other—I have forbid you, but now I recommend it.

SP.SPEAKER: Booze.
SP.P: What a torrent!

SP.SPEAKER: Wheat.
SP.P: It will be our turn by and by.

SP.SPEAKER: Ph.
SP.P: My dear mama, I am rejoiced.

SP.SPEAKER: Din.
SP.P: Stop, let me speak—What was I saying, I for∣get where I left off.

SP.SPEAKER: Wheat.
SP.P: Then you had better begin again.

SP.SPEAKER: Booze.
SP.P: S'Blood we've had enough.

SP.SPEAKER: Wheat,
SP.P: ha, ha, ha!

SP.SPEAKER: Booze.
SP.P: This laughing won't pay my debts—If I was but clear in the world, I shou'd not care a fig for any thing.

SP.SPEAKER: Wheat.
SP.P: Give me your hand, I'll take care to settle your demands—for tho' I'm not to be your relation, you shall always find me your friend.

SP.SPEAKER: Booze.
SP.P: If so, come and kiss me Dame, and now you may talk as fast as you please. Henceforth I will follow Belphegor's advice, and look for happiness in my own little family, by my own cheerful fireside. What say you Mr Justice.

SP.SPEAKER: Sol.
SP.P: I say nothing.

SP.SPEAKER: Booze.
SP.L: Free from cares that daily wait,
To rend the bosoms of the great,
Our riches and our joys shall be,

SP.SPEAKER: Chorus.
SP.L: Free from the cares that daily wait,
To rend the bosoms of the great,
Our riches and our joys shall be,

SP.SPEAKER: Din.
SP.L: No more for fancied bliss we'll roam,
We'll sigh, we'll sigh for state no more,
And when we seek our humble home,
Content, content, shall ope the door.

SP.SPEAKER: Booze.
SP.L: Thus happy in the rustic cot;
Repine at no one's brighter lot:
But keep this plan in view.

SP.SPEAKER: Colin.
SP.L: Our swains no warlike weapons weild,
With peaceful arms we grace the field;

SP.SPEAKER: Booze.
SP.L: And while we live, the life we love
Our sports shall our contentment prov,
And this shall be our song.
Free from the cares that daily wait,
To rend the bosoms of the great
Our riches and our joys shall be
